title: How to Make a Banana Hair Mask

methods.name: Preparing a Banana Milkshake Hair Mask

steps.headline: Mash or puree 1 to 2 bananas.
steps.description: Break the bananas up into a blender or food processor, and puree them until they have the consistency of a thick paste. Make sure that the mixture doesn’t have any lumps because they’ll stick to your hair and be difficult to wash out. If your hair is extremely long, you may need up to 3 bananas for the mask. You can also break the bananas up into a bowl, and use a fork or stick blender to mash them.

steps.headline: Stream in the milk.
steps.description: Once the banana is mashed into a paste, drizzle up to ¼ cup (59 ml) of whole or coconut milk into the blender or food processor to thin the mixture. Mix the two together until you reach the consistency of commercial hair conditioner. The calcium and proteins in milk restore shine and strengthen the hair. Its lactic acid also removes debris to leave hair softer. It’s best to start with a small amount of milk, mix in it, and then check the consistency. Only add more milk if the mask is too thick.

steps.headline: Apply the mask to dry hair from the roots down.
steps.description: Once the mask is the right consistency, being massaging it into your hair while it’s dry from the scalp to the ends. Use as much of the mask as you can to ensure that your hair is completely saturated with it. Work over a sink or bathtub in case any of the mask drips off your hair.

steps.headline: Cover your hair and let the mask sit for 20 minutes.
steps.description: To keep the mask from falling off your hair, put on a shower cap or wrap your head with plastic wrap. Next, allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair.

steps.headline: Wash and condition your hair as normal.
steps.description: When you've let the mask soak in for at least 15 minutes, wash it with your usual shampoo. You can follow up with conditioner, but you may find that the mask is so hydrating that you don’t need it. Rinse well to ensure that all of the banana and milk is out of your hair.

methods.name: Whipping Up a Banana and Olive Oil Hair Mask

steps.headline: Puree the banana.
steps.description: Place 1 ripe banana that’s been roughly chopped into your blender or food processor. Process it until it has a smooth, lump-free texture. You can mash the banana by hand with a fork, but work slowly to get all of the lumps out of the puree.

steps.headline: Mix in the olive oil.
steps.description: When the banana is mashed, slowly pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the blender or food processor. Blend the fruit and oil together until the mask has a creamy, frothy texture. Olive oil is full of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, such as vitamin E, that help hair maintain its moisture and protect against sun and other environmental damage.

steps.headline: Apply the mask to wet hair.
steps.description: Before applying the banana and olive oil mask, wet your hair. Massage the mixture evenly into your hair, start at your roots. Work it all the way down to the ends so all of your hair is saturated. Put the mask on your hair over the sink or in the shower to avoid making a mess on the floor.

steps.headline: Allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 minutes.
steps.description: When the mask is in place, let it sit on your hair for 10 to 15 minutes.If you're concerned about the mask dripping off, it's a good idea to put a shower cap, towel, or some plastic wrap over your hair as the mask sits.

steps.headline: Rinse the mask off with cool water.
steps.description: When the mask’s time is up, use cool water to wash it out of your hair. It may take two or three rinses to remove all of the banana from your hair so work carefully. If necessary, follow up with your usual shampoo and conditioner.

methods.name: Mixing Up a Banana and Honey Hair Mask

steps.headline: Combine the honey and banana in a food processor.
steps.description: Add ½ cup (170 g) of raw, organic honey and 2 ripe bananas that have been roughly chopped to a food processor. Blend the two together until they form a smooth puree. Honey contains polyphenols, which are antioxidants that can protect the hair from damage. It's also extremely emollient so it helps condition and moisturize your hair as well. You can also mix the mask up in a blender. For extra moisturizing, you can mix up to ½ cup (118 ml) of olive oil into the mask as well.

steps.headline: Apply the mask to dry hair.
steps.description: Massage the mask into your hair, distributing it evenly. Start at the roots and work your way down to the ends.

steps.headline: Cover your hair and allow the mask to sit for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Once the mask is on your hair, place a shower cap or plastic wrap over it. Leave the mask to sit on your head for 10 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair.

steps.headline: Rinse the mask out with water.
steps.description: After the mask has sat on your hair for at least 10 minutes, wash it out with cool to lukewarm water. You can use shampoo if you’re having trouble removing all of it. You may need to rinse your hair more than once to get all of the mask out of it.

tyn: Banana and Olive Oil Hair Mask
text: Preparing a Banana Milkshake Hair Mask Mash or puree 1 to 2 bananas. Break the bananas up into a blender or food processor, and puree them until they have the consistency of a thick paste. Make sure that the mixture doesn’t have any lumps because they’ll stick to your hair and be difficult to wash out. If your hair is extremely long, you may need up to 3 bananas for the mask. You can also break the bananas up into a bowl, and use a fork or stick blender to mash them. Stream in the milk. Once the banana is mashed into a paste, drizzle up to ¼ cup (59 ml) of whole or coconut milk into the blender or food processor to thin the mixture. Mix the two together until you reach the consistency of commercial hair conditioner. The calcium and proteins in milk restore shine and strengthen the hair. Its lactic acid also removes debris to leave hair softer. It’s best to start with a small amount of milk, mix in it, and then check the consistency. Only add more milk if the mask is too thick. Apply the mask to dry hair from the roots down. Once the mask is the right consistency, being massaging it into your hair while it’s dry from the scalp to the ends. Use as much of the mask as you can to ensure that your hair is completely saturated with it. Work over a sink or bathtub in case any of the mask drips off your hair. Cover your hair and let the mask sit for 20 minutes. To keep the mask from falling off your hair, put on a shower cap or wrap your head with plastic wrap. Next, allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair. Wash and condition your hair as normal. When you've let the mask soak in for at least 15 minutes, wash it with your usual shampoo. You can follow up with conditioner, but you may find that the mask is so hydrating that you don’t need it. Rinse well to ensure that all of the banana and milk is out of your hair. Whipping Up a Banana and Olive Oil Hair Mask Puree the banana. Place 1 ripe banana that’s been roughly chopped into your blender or food processor. Process it until it has a smooth, lump-free texture. You can mash the banana by hand with a fork, but work slowly to get all of the lumps out of the puree. Mix in the olive oil. When the banana is mashed, slowly pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the blender or food processor. Blend the fruit and oil together until the mask has a creamy, frothy texture. Olive oil is full of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, such as vitamin E, that help hair maintain its moisture and protect against sun and other environmental damage. Apply the mask to wet hair. Before applying the banana and olive oil mask, wet your hair. Massage the mixture evenly into your hair, start at your roots. Work it all the way down to the ends so all of your hair is saturated. Put the mask on your hair over the sink or in the shower to avoid making a mess on the floor. Allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 minutes. When the mask is in place, let it sit on your hair for 10 to 15 minutes.If you're concerned about the mask dripping off, it's a good idea to put a shower cap, towel, or some plastic wrap over your hair as the mask sits. Rinse the mask off with cool water. When the mask’s time is up, use cool water to wash it out of your hair. It may take two or three rinses to remove all of the banana from your hair so work carefully. If necessary, follow up with your usual shampoo and conditioner. Mixing Up a Banana and Honey Hair Mask Combine the honey and banana in a food processor. Add ½ cup (170 g) of raw, organic honey and 2 ripe bananas that have been roughly chopped to a food processor. Blend the two together until they form a smooth puree. Honey contains polyphenols, which are antioxidants that can protect the hair from damage. It's also extremely emollient so it helps condition and moisturize your hair as well. You can also mix the mask up in a blender. For extra moisturizing, you can mix up to ½ cup (118 ml) of olive oil into the mask as well. Apply the mask to dry hair. Massage the mask into your hair, distributing it evenly. Start at the roots and work your way down to the ends. Cover your hair and allow the mask to sit for 20 minutes. Once the mask is on your hair, place a shower cap or plastic wrap over it. Leave the mask to sit on your head for 10 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair. Rinse the mask out with water. After the mask has sat on your hair for at least 10 minutes, wash it out with cool to lukewarm water. You can use shampoo if you’re having trouble removing all of it. You may need to rinse your hair more than once to get all of the mask out of it.
sentences: Preparing a Banana Milkshake Hair Mask Mash or puree 1 to 2 bananas.
Break the bananas up into a blender or food processor, and puree them until they have the consistency of a thick paste.
Make sure that the mixture doesn’t have any lumps because they’ll stick to your hair and be difficult to wash out.
If your hair is extremely long, you may need up to 3 bananas for the mask.
You can also break the bananas up into a bowl, and use a fork or stick blender to mash them.
Stream in the milk.
Once the banana is mashed into a paste, drizzle up to ¼ cup (59 ml) of whole or coconut milk into the blender or food processor to thin the mixture.
Mix the two together until you reach the consistency of commercial hair conditioner.
The calcium and proteins in milk restore shine and strengthen the hair.
Its lactic acid also removes debris to leave hair softer.
It’s best to start with a small amount of milk, mix in it, and then check the consistency.
Only add more milk if the mask is too thick.
Apply the mask to dry hair from the roots down.
Once the mask is the right consistency, being massaging it into your hair while it’s dry from the scalp to the ends.
Use as much of the mask as you can to ensure that your hair is completely saturated with it.
Work over a sink or bathtub in case any of the mask drips off your hair.
Cover your hair and let the mask sit for 20 minutes.
To keep the mask from falling off your hair, put on a shower cap or wrap your head with plastic wrap.
Next, allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair.
Wash and condition your hair as normal.
When you've let the mask soak in for at least 15 minutes, wash it with your usual shampoo.
You can follow up with conditioner, but you may find that the mask is so hydrating that you don’t need it.
Rinse well to ensure that all of the banana and milk is out of your hair.
Whipping Up a Banana and Olive Oil Hair Mask Puree the banana.
Place 1 ripe banana that’s been roughly chopped into your blender or food processor.
Process it until it has a smooth, lump-free texture.
You can mash the banana by hand with a fork, but work slowly to get all of the lumps out of the puree.
Mix in the olive oil.
When the banana is mashed, slowly pour 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil into the blender or food processor.
Blend the fruit and oil together until the mask has a creamy, frothy texture.
Olive oil is full of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants, such as vitamin E, that help hair maintain its moisture and protect against sun and other environmental damage.
Apply the mask to wet hair.
Before applying the banana and olive oil mask, wet your hair.
Massage the mixture evenly into your hair, start at your roots.
Work it all the way down to the ends so all of your hair is saturated.
Put the mask on your hair over the sink or in the shower to avoid making a mess on the floor.
Allow the mask to sit on your hair for 15 minutes.

When the mask is in place, let it sit on your hair for 10 to 15 minutes.If you're concerned about the mask dripping off, it's a good idea to put a shower cap, towel, or some plastic wrap over your hair as the mask sits.
Rinse the mask off with cool water.
When the mask’s time is up, use cool water to wash it out of your hair.
It may take two or three rinses to remove all of the banana from your hair so work carefully.
If necessary, follow up with your usual shampoo and conditioner.
Mixing Up a Banana and Honey Hair Mask Combine the honey and banana in a food processor.
Add ½ cup (170 g) of raw, organic honey and 2 ripe bananas that have been roughly chopped to a food processor.
Blend the two together until they form a smooth puree.
Honey contains polyphenols, which are antioxidants that can protect the hair from damage.
It's also extremely emollient so it helps condition and moisturize your hair as well.
You can also mix the mask up in a blender.
For extra moisturizing, you can mix up to ½ cup (118 ml) of olive oil into the mask as well.
Apply the mask to dry hair.
Massage the mask into your hair, distributing it evenly.
Start at the roots and work your way down to the ends.
Cover your hair and allow the mask to sit for 20 minutes.
Once the mask is on your hair, place a shower cap or plastic wrap over it.
Leave the mask to sit on your head for 10 to 20 minutes so it has time to really condition your hair.
Rinse the mask out with water.
After the mask has sat on your hair for at least 10 minutes, wash it out with cool to lukewarm water.
You can use shampoo if you’re having trouble removing all of it.
You may need to rinse your hair more than once to get all of the mask out of it.
